unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about tax laws in India, especially for small businesses. Let me try to break it down, but remember, I'm just some random dude on Quora, not a CA! Consult a real professional for actual advice, ok?
normalised: Okay, so someone asked about tax laws in India, especially for small businesses. Let me try to break it down, but remember, I'm just some random dude on Quora, not a C-A! Consult a real professional for actual advice, okay?

unnormalised: First off, the Income Tax Act of 1961 is your bible (or the equivalent for other religions!). It's long and boring, but it's got everything. Then, depending on what kind of business you have – sole proprietorship, partnership, pvt ltd, etc. – different rules apply. So, figure that out first. You can register as proprietorship with just your PAN card, but if you are pvt ltd, there are many other requirements.
normalised: First off, the Income Tax Act of one thousand nine hundred and sixty one is your bible (or the equivalent for other religions!). It's long and boring, but it's got everything. Then, depending on what kind of business you have – sole proprietorship, partnership, private limited, etcetera – different rules apply. So, figure that out first. You can register as proprietorship with just your P-A-N card, but if you are private limited, there are many other requirements.

unnormalised: Now, for the nitty-gritty. GST (Goods and Services Tax) is a big deal. If your annual turnover is more than Rs. 20 lakhs (or 10 lakhs in some special category states), you gotta register. GST registration is must for entities doing interstate trade. It's a whole other beast with different rates for different goods/services. Check out the GST website for all the details. Filing it monthly can be a pain, especially GSTR-3B and GSTR-1. Keep all your invoices and receipts organized, or you'll be crying later.
normalised: Now, for the nitty-gritty. G-S-T (Goods and Services Tax) is a big deal. If your annual turnover is more than rupee twenty lakhs (or ten lakhs in some special category states), you gotta register. G-S-T registration is must for entities doing interstate trade. It's a whole other beast with different rates for different goods or services. Check out the G-S-T website for all the details. Filing it monthly can be a pain, especially G-S-T-R-three-B and G-S-T-R-one. Keep all your invoices and receipts organized, or you'll be crying later.

unnormalised: Income tax is another story. You need to file ITR (Income Tax Return) every year, even if you didn’t earn any profit. The due date is usually 31st July, but it can get extended, so keep an eye out for notifications from the IT dept. There are different ITR forms depending on your income and business type. ITR-4 is common for small businesses opting for the presumptive taxation scheme (more on that later). Remember, filing after the due date attracts a penalty, as per section 234F.
normalised: Income tax is another story. You need to file I-T-R (Income Tax Return) every year, even if you didn’t earn any profit. The due date is usually thirty first July, but it can get extended, so keep an eye out for notifications from the I-T department. There are different I-T-R forms depending on your income and business type. I-T-R-four is common for small businesses opting for the presumptive taxation scheme (more on that later). Remember, filing after the due date attracts a penalty, as per section two hundred and thirty four F.

unnormalised: About that presumptive taxation scheme (Sec 44AD/ADA). It's for businesses with a turnover of less than Rs. 2 crores. Basically, you declare a certain percentage of your turnover as profit (usually 6% for digital transactions or 8% for others), and you pay tax on that. It's way simpler than keeping detailed books of accounts. But there are conditions, so read up on it before opting in. 44ADA is for professionals like doctors, lawyers, etc., and they can declare 50% of gross receipts as profit. I think the current rate is 50%.
normalised: About that presumptive taxation scheme (Section forty four A-D slash A-D-A). It's for businesses with a turnover of less than rupee two crores. Basically, you declare a certain percentage of your turnover as profit (usually six percent for digital transactions or eight percent for others), and you pay tax on that. It's way simpler than keeping detailed books of accounts. But there are conditions, so read up on it before opting in. forty four A-D-A is for professionals like doctors, lawyers, etcetera, and they can declare fifty percent of gross receipts as profit. I think the current rate is fifty percent.

unnormalised: TDS (Tax Deducted at Source) is important if you’re making payments to others. If you're paying above a certain threshold (e.g., Rs. 30,000 to a contractor), you need to deduct TDS and deposit it with the government. You also need to issue TDS certificates to the deductees (Form 16A). Failing to do so can result in penalties. TDS rates vary depending on the type of payment.
normalised: T-D-S (Tax Deducted at Source) is important if you’re making payments to others. If you're paying above a certain threshold (for example, rupee thirty thousand to a contractor), you need to deduct T-D-S and deposit it with the government. You also need to issue T-D-S certificates to the deductees (Form sixteen A). Failing to do so can result in penalties. T-D-S rates vary depending on the type of payment.

unnormalised: Also, don't forget about advance tax. If your estimated tax liability for the year is more than Rs. 10,000, you need to pay advance tax in installments throughout the year. The due dates are usually 15th June, 15th September, 15th December, and 15th March. Paying it on time avoids interest charges under section 234C. A challan 280 is used to deposit this tax.
normalised: Also, don't forget about advance tax. If your estimated tax liability for the year is more than rupee ten thousand, you need to pay advance tax in installments throughout the year. The due dates are usually fifteenth June, fifteenth September, fifteenth December, and fifteenth March. Paying it on time avoids interest charges under section two hundred and thirty four C. A challan two hundred and eighty is used to deposit this tax.
